div.p: Isostructural phase transformations (ISPhTs) are particular cases of isosymmetric transformations and include discontinuous isostructural transitions and crossovers. They are rare, intriguing phenomena in solids often associated with a significant volume collapse, giant magneto-elastic coupling, or negative thermal expansion. So far ISPhTs were reported for heavy elements and their compounds with complex electronic and/or magnetic structures. We have studied the high-pressure boron phase γ-B 28 by means of in situ single-crystal X-ray diffraction in diamond anvil cells at ID09a above and Raman spectroscopy at megabar pressure range. The discontinuous behavior of the Raman modes and the abrupt changes in the compressional behavior of γ-B 28 are manifestations of the isostructural phase transformation at about 40 GPa (Fig. 1). The combined experimental and ab inito theoretical analysis of the structural and vibrational properties of γ-B 28 suggest that the ISPhT under compression is due to the weakening of the polarity of the covalent bonds between the boron atoms in the complex quasimolecular structure of γ-B 28 .
